newsitem.title: TAIWAN: China ship enters Taiwan port in historic passage.
newsitem.headline: China ship enters Taiwan port in historic passage.

text.p: The first ship to sail directly to Taiwan from mainland China in 48 years entered Kaohsiung port on Saturday, completing a historic crossing of one of the world's great political divides.
"The Sheng Da is here," Kaohsiung port tower control manager David Wu said as the mainland-owned, Saint Vincent-registered Sheng Da passed a light buoy marking the port's Taiwan strait boundary.

A Reuters correspondent in the tower said the 6,000-tonne ship entered port flying the flag of the Nationalist Republic of China that rules Taiwan, which apparently had been put aboard by a pilot craft sent to greet it. No other flags could be seen from the tower.

The ship was carrying a relatively light load of containers, which will be forwarded from Kaohsiung to third countries. Under Taiwan regulations banning direct links with mainland China the cargo cannot enter Taiwan customs.

The Sheng Da's arrival completed the first authorised crossing of the heavily militarised ideological divide since 1949, when a civil war put communists in control of the Chinese mainland and the defeated Nationalists in charge on Taiwan.
Taipei in mid-April gave a green light for five mainland carriers to start cross-straits service. Beijing reciprocated on Thursday with permits for six Taiwan firms.
